built with pdoc

flavors_numpy

Example NumPy-style docstrings.

This module demonstrates documentation as specified by the NumPy Documentation HOWTO. Docstrings may extend over multiple lines. Sections are created with a section header followed by an underline of equal length.

Example

Examples can be given using either the Example or Examples sections. Sections support any reStructuredText formatting, including literal blocks::

$ python example_numpy.py

Section breaks are created with two blank lines. Section breaks are also implicitly created anytime a new section starts. Section bodies may be indented:

Notes

This is an example of an indented section. It's like any other section, but the body is indented to help it stand out from surrounding text. If a section is indented, then a section break is created by resuming unindented text.

Attributes

  • module_level_variable1 (int): Module level variables may be documented in either the Attributes section of the module docstring, or in an inline docstring immediately following the variable.

    Either form is acceptable, but the two should not be mixed. Choose one convention to document module level variables and be consistent with it.

  1# Examples taken from:
  2#
  3# - The Napoleon documentation at https://sphinxcontrib-napoleon.readthedocs.io/en/latest/example_numpy.html
  4#   License: BSD-3
  5# - https://github.com/numpy/numpydoc/blob/main/doc/example.py
  6#   License: BSD-2
  7#
  8# flake8: noqa
  9# fmt: off
 10"""Example NumPy-style docstrings.
 11
 12This module demonstrates documentation as specified by the `NumPy
 13Documentation HOWTO`_. Docstrings may extend over multiple lines. Sections
 14are created with a section header followed by an underline of equal length.
 15
 16Example
 17-------
 18Examples can be given using either the ``Example`` or ``Examples``
 19sections. Sections support any reStructuredText formatting, including
 20literal blocks::
 21
 22    $ python example_numpy.py
 23
 24
 25Section breaks are created with two blank lines. Section breaks are also
 26implicitly created anytime a new section starts. Section bodies *may* be
 27indented:
 28
 29Notes
 30-----
 31    This is an example of an indented section. It's like any other section,
 32    but the body is indented to help it stand out from surrounding text.
 33
 34If a section is indented, then a section break is created by
 35resuming unindented text.
 36
 37Attributes
 38----------
 39module_level_variable1 : int
 40    Module level variables may be documented in either the ``Attributes``
 41    section of the module docstring, or in an inline docstring immediately
 42    following the variable.
 43
 44    Either form is acceptable, but the two should not be mixed. Choose
 45    one convention to document module level variables and be consistent
 46    with it.
 47
 48
 49.. _NumPy Documentation HOWTO:
 50   https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/master/doc/HOWTO_DOCUMENT.rst.txt
 51
 52"""
 53__docformat__ = "numpy"
 54
 55
 56module_level_variable1 = 12345
 57
 58module_level_variable2 = 98765
 59"""int: Module level variable documented inline.
 60
 61The docstring may span multiple lines. The type may optionally be specified
 62on the first line, separated by a colon.
 63"""
 64
 65
 66def function_with_types_in_docstring(param1, param2):
 67    """Example function with types documented in the docstring.
 68
 69    `PEP 484`_ type annotations are supported. If attribute, parameter, and
 70    return types are annotated according to `PEP 484`_, they do not need to be
 71    included in the docstring:
 72
 73    Parameters
 74    ----------
 75    param1 : int
 76        The first parameter.
 77    param2 : str
 78        The second parameter.
 79
 80    Returns
 81    -------
 82    bool
 83        True if successful, False otherwise.
 84
 85    .. _PEP 484:
 86        https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0484/
 87
 88    """
 89
 90
 91def function_with_pep484_type_annotations(param1: int, param2: str) -> bool:
 92    """Example function with PEP 484 type annotations.
 93
 94    The return type must be duplicated in the docstring to comply
 95    with the NumPy docstring style.
 96
 97    Parameters
 98    ----------
 99    param1
100        The first parameter.
101    param2
102        The second parameter.
103
104    Returns
105    -------
106    bool
107        True if successful, False otherwise.
108
109    """
110
111
112def module_level_function(param1, param2=None, *args, **kwargs):
113    """This is an example of a module level function.
114
115    Function parameters should be documented in the ``Parameters`` section.
116    The name of each parameter is required. The type and description of each
117    parameter is optional, but should be included if not obvious.
118
119    If *args or **kwargs are accepted,
120    they should be listed as ``*args`` and ``**kwargs``.
121
122    The format for a parameter is::
123
124        name : type
125            description
126
127            The description may span multiple lines. Following lines
128            should be indented to match the first line of the description.
129            The ": type" is optional.
130
131            Multiple paragraphs are supported in parameter
132            descriptions.
133
134    Parameters
135    ----------
136    param1 : int
137        The first parameter.
138    param2 : :obj:`str`, optional
139        The second parameter.
140    *args
141        Variable length argument list.
142    **kwargs
143        Arbitrary keyword arguments.
144
145    Returns
146    -------
147    bool
148        True if successful, False otherwise.
149
150        The return type is not optional. The ``Returns`` section may span
151        multiple lines and paragraphs. Following lines should be indented to
152        match the first line of the description.
153
154        The ``Returns`` section supports any reStructuredText formatting,
155        including literal blocks::
156
157            {
158                'param1': param1,
159                'param2': param2
160            }
161
162    Raises
163    ------
164    AttributeError
165        The ``Raises`` section is a list of all exceptions
166        that are relevant to the interface.
167    ValueError
168        If `param2` is equal to `param1`.
169
170    """
171    if param1 == param2:
172        raise ValueError('param1 may not be equal to param2')
173    return True
174
175
176def example_generator(n):
177    """Generators have a ``Yields`` section instead of a ``Returns`` section.
178
179    Parameters
180    ----------
181    n : int
182        The upper limit of the range to generate, from 0 to `n` - 1.
183
184    Yields
185    ------
186    int
187        The next number in the range of 0 to `n` - 1.
188
189    Examples
190    --------
191    Examples should be written in doctest format, and should illustrate how
192    to use the function.
193
194    >>> print([i for i in example_generator(4)])
195    [0, 1, 2, 3]
196
197    """
198    for i in range(n):
199        yield i
200
201
202class ExampleError(Exception):
203    """Exceptions are documented in the same way as classes.
204
205    The __init__ method may be documented in either the class level
206    docstring, or as a docstring on the __init__ method itself.
207
208    Either form is acceptable, but the two should not be mixed. Choose one
209    convention to document the __init__ method and be consistent with it.
210
211    Note
212    ----
213    Do not include the `self` parameter in the ``Parameters`` section.
214
215    Parameters
216    ----------
217    msg : str
218        Human readable string describing the exception.
219    code : :obj:`int`, optional
220        Numeric error code.
221
222    Attributes
223    ----------
224    msg : str
225        Human readable string describing the exception.
226    code : int
227        Numeric error code.
228
229    """
230
231    def __init__(self, msg, code):
232        self.msg = msg
233        self.code = code
234
235
236class ExampleClass(object):
237    """The summary line for a class docstring should fit on one line.
238
239    If the class has public attributes, they may be documented here
240    in an ``Attributes`` section and follow the same formatting as a
241    function's ``Args`` section. Alternatively, attributes may be documented
242    inline with the attribute's declaration (see __init__ method below).
243
244    Properties created with the ``@property`` decorator should be documented
245    in the property's getter method.
246
247    Attributes
248    ----------
249    attr1 : str
250        Description of `attr1`.
251    attr2 : :obj:`int`, optional
252        Description of `attr2`.
253
254    """
255
256    def __init__(self, param1, param2, param3):
257        """Example of docstring on the __init__ method.
258
259        The __init__ method may be documented in either the class level
260        docstring, or as a docstring on the __init__ method itself.
261
262        Either form is acceptable, but the two should not be mixed. Choose one
263        convention to document the __init__ method and be consistent with it.
264
265        Note
266        ----
267        Do not include the `self` parameter in the ``Parameters`` section.
268
269        Parameters
270        ----------
271        param1 : str
272            Description of `param1`.
273        param2 : :obj:`list` of :obj:`str`
274            Description of `param2`. Multiple
275            lines are supported.
276        param3 : :obj:`int`, optional
277            Description of `param3`.
278
279        """
280        self.attr1 = param1
281        self.attr2 = param2
282        self.attr3 = param3  #: Doc comment *inline* with attribute
283
284        #: list of str: Doc comment *before* attribute, with type specified
285        self.attr4 = ["attr4"]
286
287        self.attr5 = None
288        """str: Docstring *after* attribute, with type specified."""
289
290    @property
291    def readonly_property(self):
292        """str: Properties should be documented in their getter method."""
293        return "readonly_property"
294
295    @property
296    def readwrite_property(self):
297        """:obj:`list` of :obj:`str`: Properties with both a getter and setter
298        should only be documented in their getter method.
299
300        If the setter method contains notable behavior, it should be
301        mentioned here.
302        """
303        return ["readwrite_property"]
304
305    @readwrite_property.setter
306    def readwrite_property(self, value):
307        value
308
309    def example_method(self, param1, param2):
310        """Class methods are similar to regular functions.
311
312        Note
313        ----
314        Do not include the `self` parameter in the ``Parameters`` section.
315
316        Parameters
317        ----------
318        param1
319            The first parameter.
320        param2
321            The second parameter.
322
323        Returns
324        -------
325        bool
326            True if successful, False otherwise.
327
328        """
329        return True
330
331    def __special__(self):
332        """By default special members with docstrings are not included.
333
334        Special members are any methods or attributes that start with and
335        end with a double underscore. Any special member with a docstring
336        will be included in the output, if
337        ``napoleon_include_special_with_doc`` is set to True.
338
339        This behavior can be enabled by changing the following setting in
340        Sphinx's conf.py::
341
342            napoleon_include_special_with_doc = True
343
344        """
345        pass
346
347    def __special_without_docstring__(self):
348        pass
349
350    def _private(self):
351        """By default private members are not included.
352
353        Private members are any methods or attributes that start with an
354        underscore and are *not* special. By default they are not included
355        in the output.
356
357        This behavior can be changed such that private members *are* included
358        by changing the following setting in Sphinx's conf.py::
359
360            napoleon_include_private_with_doc = True
361
362        """
363        pass
364
365    def _private_without_docstring(self):
366        pass
367
368
369def foo(var1, var2, *args, long_var_name='hi', **kwargs):
370    r"""Summarize the function in one line.
371
372    Several sentences providing an extended description. Refer to
373    variables using back-ticks, e.g. `var`.
374
375    Parameters
376    ----------
377    var1 : array_like
378        Array_like means all those objects -- lists, nested lists, etc. --
379        that can be converted to an array.  We can also refer to
380        variables like `var1`.
381    var2 : int
382        The type above can either refer to an actual Python type
383        (e.g. ``int``), or describe the type of the variable in more
384        detail, e.g. ``(N,) ndarray`` or ``array_like``.
385    *args : iterable
386        Other arguments.
387    long_var_name : {'hi', 'ho'}, optional
388        Choices in brackets, default first when optional.
389    **kwargs : dict
390        Keyword arguments.
391
392    Returns
393    -------
394    type
395        Explanation of anonymous return value of type ``type``.
396    describe : type
397        Explanation of return value named `describe`.
398    out : type
399        Explanation of `out`.
400    type_without_description
401
402    Other Parameters
403    ----------------
404    only_seldom_used_keywords : type
405        Explanation.
406    common_parameters_listed_above : type
407        Explanation.
408
409    Raises
410    ------
411    BadException
412        Because you shouldn't have done that.
413
414    See Also
415    --------
416    numpy.array : Relationship (optional).
417    numpy.ndarray : Relationship (optional), which could be fairly long, in
418                    which case the line wraps here.
419    numpy.dot, numpy.linalg.norm, numpy.eye
420
421    Notes
422    -----
423    Notes about the implementation algorithm (if needed).
424
425    This can have multiple paragraphs.
426
427    You may include some math:
428
429    .. math:: X(e^{j\omega } ) = x(n)e^{ - j\omega n}
430
431    And even use a Greek symbol like :math:`\omega` inline.
432
433    References
434    ----------
435    Cite the relevant literature, e.g. [1]_.  You may also cite these
436    references in the notes section above.
437
438    .. [1] O. McNoleg, "The integration of GIS, remote sensing,
439       expert systems and adaptive co-kriging for environmental habitat
440       modelling of the Highland Haggis using object-oriented, fuzzy-logic
441       and neural-network techniques," Computers & Geosciences, vol. 22,
442       pp. 585-588, 1996.
443
444    Examples
445    --------
446    These are written in doctest format, and should illustrate how to
447    use the function.
448
449    >>> a = [1, 2, 3]
450    >>> print([x + 3 for x in a])
451    [4, 5, 6]
452    >>> print("a\nb")
453    a
454    b
455    """
456    # After closing class docstring, there should be one blank line to
457    # separate following codes (according to PEP257).
458    # But for function, method and module, there should be no blank lines
459    # after closing the docstring.
460    pass
461
462
463def invalid_format(test):
464    """
465    In this example, there is no description for the test argument
466
467    Parameters
468    ----------
469    param1
470
471    """

PEP 484 type annotations are supported. If attribute, parameter, and return types are annotated according to PEP 484, they do not need to be included in the docstring:

Parameters

  • param2 (str): The second parameter.
Returns

def module_level_function(param1, param2=None, *args, **kwargs): 
113def module_level_function(param1, param2=None, *args, **kwargs):
114    """This is an example of a module level function.
115
116    Function parameters should be documented in the ``Parameters`` section.
117    The name of each parameter is required. The type and description of each
118    parameter is optional, but should be included if not obvious.
119
120    If *args or **kwargs are accepted,
121    they should be listed as ``*args`` and ``**kwargs``.
122
123    The format for a parameter is::
124
125        name : type
126            description
127
128            The description may span multiple lines. Following lines
129            should be indented to match the first line of the description.
130            The ": type" is optional.
131
132            Multiple paragraphs are supported in parameter
133            descriptions.
134
135    Parameters
136    ----------
137    param1 : int
138        The first parameter.
139    param2 : :obj:`str`, optional
140        The second parameter.
141    *args
142        Variable length argument list.
143    **kwargs
144        Arbitrary keyword arguments.
145
146    Returns
147    -------
148    bool
149        True if successful, False otherwise.
150
151        The return type is not optional. The ``Returns`` section may span
152        multiple lines and paragraphs. Following lines should be indented to
153        match the first line of the description.
154
155        The ``Returns`` section supports any reStructuredText formatting,
156        including literal blocks::
157
158            {
159                'param1': param1,
160                'param2': param2
161            }
162
163    Raises
164    ------
165    AttributeError
166        The ``Raises`` section is a list of all exceptions
167        that are relevant to the interface.
168    ValueError
169        If `param2` is equal to `param1`.
170
171    """
172    if param1 == param2:
173        raise ValueError('param1 may not be equal to param2')
174    return True

This is an example of a module level function.

Function parameters should be documented in the Parameters section. The name of each parameter is required. The type and description of each parameter is optional, but should be included if not obvious.

If args or *kwargs are accepted, they should be listed as *args and **kwargs.

The format for a parameter is::

name : type
    description

    The description may span multiple lines. Following lines
    should be indented to match the first line of the description.
    The ": type" is optional.

    Multiple paragraphs are supported in parameter
    descriptions.
Parameters
  • param1 (int): The first parameter.
  • param2 (str, optional): The second parameter.
  • *args: Variable length argument list.
  • **kwargs: Arbitrary keyword arguments.
Returns
  • bool: True if successful, False otherwise.

The return type is not optional. The Returns section may span multiple lines and paragraphs. Following lines should be indented to match the first line of the description.

The Returns section supports any reStructuredText formatting, including literal blocks::

{
    'param1': param1,
    'param2': param2
}
Raises
  • AttributeError: The Raises section is a list of all exceptions that are relevant to the interface.
  • ValueError: If param2 is equal to param1.
def example_generator(n): 
177def example_generator(n):
178    """Generators have a ``Yields`` section instead of a ``Returns`` section.
179
180    Parameters
181    ----------
182    n : int
183        The upper limit of the range to generate, from 0 to `n` - 1.
184
185    Yields
186    ------
187    int
188        The next number in the range of 0 to `n` - 1.
189
190    Examples
191    --------
192    Examples should be written in doctest format, and should illustrate how
193    to use the function.
194
195    >>> print([i for i in example_generator(4)])
196    [0, 1, 2, 3]
197
198    """
199    for i in range(n):
200        yield i

Generators have a Yields section instead of a Returns section.

Parameters
  • n (int): The upper limit of the range to generate, from 0 to n - 1.
Yields
  • int: The next number in the range of 0 to n - 1.
Examples

Examples should be written in doctest format, and should illustrate how to use the function.

>>> print([i for i in example_generator(4)])
[0, 1, 2, 3]
class ExampleError(builtins.Exception): 
203class ExampleError(Exception):
204    """Exceptions are documented in the same way as classes.
205
206    The __init__ method may be documented in either the class level
207    docstring, or as a docstring on the __init__ method itself.
208
209    Either form is acceptable, but the two should not be mixed. Choose one
210    convention to document the __init__ method and be consistent with it.
211
212    Note
213    ----
214    Do not include the `self` parameter in the ``Parameters`` section.
215
216    Parameters
217    ----------
218    msg : str
219        Human readable string describing the exception.
220    code : :obj:`int`, optional
221        Numeric error code.
222
223    Attributes
224    ----------
225    msg : str
226        Human readable string describing the exception.
227    code : int
228        Numeric error code.
229
230    """
231
232    def __init__(self, msg, code):
233        self.msg = msg
234        self.code = code

Exceptions are documented in the same way as classes.

The __init__ method may be documented in either the class level docstring, or as a docstring on the __init__ method itself.

Either form is acceptable, but the two should not be mixed. Choose one convention to document the __init__ method and be consistent with it.

Note

Do not include the self parameter in the Parameters section.

Parameters
  • msg (str): Human readable string describing the exception.
  • code (int, optional): Numeric error code.
Attributes
  • msg (str): Human readable string describing the exception.
  • code (int): Numeric error code.
ExampleError(msg, code) 
232    def __init__(self, msg, code):
233        self.msg = msg
234        self.code = code

241    in an ``Attributes`` section and follow the same formatting as a
242    function's ``Args`` section. Alternatively, attributes may be documented
243    inline with the attribute's declaration (see __init__ method below).
244

246    in the property's getter method.

348    def __special_without_docstring__(self):
349        pass
350
351    def _private(self):
352        """By default private members are not included.
353
354        Private members are any methods or attributes that start with an
355        underscore and are *not* special. By default they are not included
356        in the output.
357
358        This behavior can be changed such that private members *are* included
359        by changing the following setting in Sphinx's conf.py::
360
361            napoleon_include_private_with_doc = True
362
363        """
364        pass
365
366    def _private_without_docstring(self):
367        pass

The summary line for a class docstring should fit on one line.

If the class has public attributes, they may be documented here in an Attributes section and follow the same formatting as a function's Args section. Alternatively, attributes may be documented inline with the attribute's declaration (see __init__ method below).

Properties created with the @property decorator should be documented in the property's getter method.

Attributes
  • attr1 (str): Description of attr1.
  • attr2 (int, optional): Description of attr2.
ExampleClass(param1, param2, param3) 
257    def __init__(self, param1, param2, param3):
258        """Example of docstring on the __init__ method.
259
260        The __init__ method may be documented in either the class level
261        docstring, or as a docstring on the __init__ method itself.
262
263        Either form is acceptable, but the two should not be mixed. Choose one
264        convention to document the __init__ method and be consistent with it.
265
266        Note
267        ----
268        Do not include the `self` parameter in the ``Parameters`` section.
269
270        Parameters
271        ----------
272        param1 : str
273            Description of `param1`.
274        param2 : :obj:`list` of :obj:`str`
275            Description of `param2`. Multiple
276            lines are supported.
277        param3 : :obj:`int`, optional
278            Description of `param3`.
279
280        """
281        self.attr1 = param1
282        self.attr2 = param2
283        self.attr3 = param3  #: Doc comment *inline* with attribute
284
285        #: list of str: Doc comment *before* attribute, with type specified
286        self.attr4 = ["attr4"]
287
288        self.attr5 = None
289        """str: Docstring *after* attribute, with type specified."""

Example of docstring on the __init__ method.

The __init__ method may be documented in either the class level docstring, or as a docstring on the __init__ method itself.

Either form is acceptable, but the two should not be mixed. Choose one convention to document the __init__ method and be consistent with it.

Note

Do not include the self parameter in the Parameters section.

Parameters
  • param1 (str): Description of param1.
  • param2 (list of str): Description of param2. Multiple lines are supported.
  • param3 (int, optional): Description of param3.
attr5

str: Docstring after attribute, with type specified.

readonly_property

str: Properties should be documented in their getter method.

readwrite_property

list of str: Properties with both a getter and setter should only be documented in their getter method.

If the setter method contains notable behavior, it should be mentioned here.

def example_method(self, param1, param2):

311        """Class methods are similar to regular functions.
312
313        Note
314        ----
315        Do not include the `self` parameter in the ``Parameters`` section.
316
317        Parameters
318        ----------
319        param1
320            The first parameter.
321        param2
322            The second parameter.
323
324        Returns
325        -------
326        bool
327            True if successful, False otherwise.
328
329        """
330        return True

Class methods are similar to regular functions.

Note

Do not include the self parameter in the Parameters section.

Parameters
  • param1: The first parameter.
  • param2: The second parameter.
Returns
  • bool: True if successful, False otherwise.
def foo(var1, var2, *args, long_var_name='hi', **kwargs): 
370def foo(var1, var2, *args, long_var_name='hi', **kwargs):
371    r"""Summarize the function in one line.
372
373    Several sentences providing an extended description. Refer to
374    variables using back-ticks, e.g. `var`.
375
376    Parameters
377    ----------
378    var1 : array_like
379        Array_like means all those objects -- lists, nested lists, etc. --
380        that can be converted to an array.  We can also refer to
381        variables like `var1`.
382    var2 : int
383        The type above can either refer to an actual Python type
384        (e.g. ``int``), or describe the type of the variable in more
385        detail, e.g. ``(N,) ndarray`` or ``array_like``.
386    *args : iterable
387        Other arguments.
388    long_var_name : {'hi', 'ho'}, optional
389        Choices in brackets, default first when optional.
390    **kwargs : dict
391        Keyword arguments.

448    use the function.

452    [4, 5, 6]
453    >>> print("a\nb")
454    a
455    b
456    """
457    # After closing class docstring, there should be one blank line to
458    # separate following codes (according to PEP257).
459    # But for function, method and module, there should be no blank lines
460    # after closing the docstring.
461    pass

Summarize the function in one line.

Several sentences providing an extended description. Refer to variables using back-ticks, e.g. var.

Parameters
  • var1 (array_like): Array_like means all those objects -- lists, nested lists, etc. -- that can be converted to an array. We can also refer to variables like var1.
  • var2 (int): The type above can either refer to an actual Python type (e.g. int), or describe the type of the variable in more detail, e.g. (N,) ndarray or array_like.
  • *args (iterable): Other arguments.
  • long_var_name ({'hi', 'ho'}, optional): Choices in brackets, default first when optional.
  • **kwargs (dict): Keyword arguments.
Returns
  • type: Explanation of anonymous return value of type type.
  • describe (type): Explanation of return value named describe.
  • out (type): Explanation of out.
  • type_without_description
Other Parameters
  • only_seldom_used_keywords (type): Explanation.
  • common_parameters_listed_above (type): Explanation.
Raises
  • BadException: Because you shouldn't have done that.
See Also

numpy.array: Relationship (optional).
numpy.ndarray: Relationship (optional), which could be fairly long, in which case the line wraps here.
numpy.dot,, numpy.linalg.norm,, numpy.eye

Notes

Notes about the implementation algorithm (if needed).

This can have multiple paragraphs.

You may include some math:

$$X(e^{j\omega } ) = x(n)e^{ - j\omega n}$$

And even use a Greek symbol like \( \omega \) inline.

References

Cite the relevant literature, e.g. 1. You may also cite these references in the notes section above.

Examples

These are written in doctest format, and should illustrate how to use the function.

>>> a = [1, 2, 3]
>>> print([x + 3 for x in a])
[4, 5, 6]
>>> print("a\nb")
a
b
